questions.text: Which of the following fetal hormones does not play any role in fetal growth?
questions.solution:
Growth hormone does not play any role in fetal growth, although it is present in high levels during the fetal period. However, it does have a role in the postnatal period. 

Insulin and thyroxine hormones are required for normal growth and development during late gestation. Glucocorticoid has a role in the prepartum maturation of organs such as liver, lungs, and gastrointestinal tract.

questions.text: A child is brought to the pediatrician for vaccination. The child is able to speak in	2-3 word sentences and is able to make a tower of 6 cubes. What is the expected weight of the child, if his development is normal and birth weight was 3 Kgs?
questions.solution:
The child is able to make a tower of 6 cubes and speaks in 2-3 word sentences which indicates the child is of 2 years of age. Birth weight quadruples by the age of 2 years. Hence the child's weight should be 3 kgs x 4= 12 Kgs.

Infants may lose up to 10% of their birth weight in the 1st week of life and regain it by their 2nd week.

Related Pearl: Weight and height changes in children

Term newborns may lose up to 10% of their birth weight in the first few days of life (due to extracellular fluid losses). Most healthy newborns typically regain their birth weight by 10 to 14 days. Thereafter, approximate daily weight gain is as follows :

  • 0-3 months ~ 30 grams/day
  • 3-6 months ~ 20 grams/day
  • 6-12months ~ 12-15 grams/day

Note : Infant weight approximately Doubles at 4-5 months , Triples by 1year and is 4 times by 2 years of age.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: Head circumference should be measured within 24 hours after birth
Head circumference equals chest circumference at 1 year of age
A boys height at 2 and half years is half of his adult height
A girls height at 2 years is half of her adult height

questions.solution:
Head circumference should not be measured within 24 hours because the head is subjected to molding during delivery, which makes the measurements unreliable.

The maximum circumference of the head from the occipital protuberance to the supraorbital ridges on the forehead is recorded using the cross-tape method.

Age Head circumference
At birth 33 to 35cm
3 m 40 cm
6 m 43 cm
1 year 46 cm
2 years 48 cm
3 years 49 cm
4 years 50 cm
12 years 52 cm (adult size)
  • Head circumference increases by the following:
    • 2 cm/month in first 3 months
    • 1 cm/month in next 3 months
    • 0.5 cm/month in next 6 months

Head circumference is more than chest circumference by 2.5 cm at birth.

  • At birth: Head circumference > Chest circumference
  • At 9-12 months: Head circumference = Chest circumference
  • After 1 year: Head circumference < Chest circumference

Interesting fact!

A boy's height at 2 and half years is half of his adult height and a girl's height at 2 years is half of her adult height.

To roughly predict adult height, use the formula:

  • Adult height = height at 2.5 years for boys (or 2 years for girls) X 2

According to WHO growth charts, the height-for-age for most of the children lies between 70-90 cm during these periods. The double of it, i.e. 140-180 cm is the average height that most of us achieve as adults.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding the eruption of teeth is false?
  1. The first primary tooth to erupt is the lower central incisor
  2. All primary teeth erupt earlier in the lower jaw than their counterparts in the upper jaw.
  3. The first secondary tooth to erupt is the first molar.
  4. No teeth till 12 months of age is called delayed eruption.
  5. Teething is manifested as gingival hyperemia and sucking fingers.
questions.solution:
Primary teeth in the upper jaw erupt earlier than their counterpart in the lower jaw, except for lower central incisors and second molar. No primary teeth till the age of 13 months is called delayed eruption.

 

As seen in the image below, the first primary tooth to erupt is the lower (mandibular) central incisor, at 5-7 months. All primary teeth erupt by 1.5–2.5 years of age. 

The first secondary tooth to erupt is the first molar (maxillary or mandibular), at 6-7 years, followed by the lower central incisor.

Causes of delayed eruption:

  • Idiopathic: Most common
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Hypoparathyroidism
  • Familial
  • Mechanical blockage of individual teeth

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presented to the clinic for a missed vaccination. His routine anthropometric measurements were noted. He was found to be 90 cm tall with a lower segment of 45 cm. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis in this child?
questions.solution:
The upper segment to lower segment (U/L) ratio in this child is 1. The U/L ratio is low for his age which makes spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia most likely among the given options.

The lower segment is defined as the length from the symphysis pubis to the floor. The upper segment is measured by subtracting the lower segment from the height.

The U/L ratio is

  • 1.7 at birth
  • 1.3 at 3 years
  • 1 after 7 years
  • 0.9 in adults

High U/L ratio:

  • Rickets
  • Achondroplasia
  • Untreated congenital hypothyroidism 

Low U/L ratio:

  • Spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia
  • Vertebral anomalies

Arm span:

  • Length between the tips of the middle finger of the outstretched hands is the arm span.
  • It is shorter than the length by 2.5 cm at birth; it equals height at 11 y and thereafter is slightly greater than height (usually<1 cm).

questions.text: A team participating in an Under-14 national athletics sports tournament suspects foul play by, a rival team member. He claims to fit the criteria for the age requirements for the tournament, but the opposing team does not agree. Which of the following X-ray would be most useful to verify the claims of the player?

choices.text: X-ray of the hands and wrist
X-ray of the elbow and hip

questions.solution:
The X-ray of choice to determine the skeletal age of a 14-year-old boy is X-ray of the elbow and hip.

The bone age of a child indicates his/her level of biological and structural maturity. Methods used for bone age estimation are Gruelisch–Pyle atlas (more common) and Tanner–Whitehouse method.

Bone age estimation
Age X-ray of choice
3 to 9 months X-ray shoulder
1 to 13 years Single film of X-ray hands and wrist
12 to 14 years X-ray elbow and hip

Note: There is overlap in the age ranges for X-ray of choice.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: Head reaches 90% of adult size at 1 year
Lymphoid growth follows a sigmoid-shaped pattern
Perinatal period is between 28 weeks of gestation to 7 days after birth
Growth of child is cephalocaudal and distal to proximal

questions.solution:
Growth of child is cephalocaudal and distal to proximal. 

During fetal life, the growth of the head occurs before that of the neck, and arms grow before legs. The distal parts of the body such as hands increase in size before the upper arms.

Growth Development
Denotes a net increase in size/mass of tissues Denotes maturation of functions

Cephalocaudal

Head ⇒ Neck ⇒ Trunk & upper limbs ⇒ Lower limbs

Distal ⇒ Proximal

Hands increase in size before upper arms

 Proximal ⇒ Distal

Hand use is learnt before the use of fingers

Growth rate of different tissues:

  • Brain growth: At age of 1 month, the head size is about 36% of the expected head size in adults. It doubles in the first year of life to 72% and becomes 83% of adult size at 2 years.
  • Lymphoid growth: It is prominent in mid-childhood. It peaks at 4–8 years and regresses subsequently.
  • Gonadal growth: It stays dormant during childhood and shows a rise with the onset of puberty.
  • Somatic growth: General body growth shows an S-shaped curve. It is rapid during the fetal period and the first 3–4 years. It is steady in the following period, followed by a growth spurt during puberty. Later, it slows down considerably.

Note: WHO defines the perinatal period from 22 weeks of gestation (or ≥500 g) up to 7 days after birth.

  • Order of Growth: Distal ⇒ Proximal 
  • Order of Development: Proximal ⇒ Distal

questions.text: A young boy is brought to the clinician by his parents with complaints of impulsive behavior and decreased levels of attention at school and everyday activities. The clinician is suspecting a case of ADHD. Which of the following is not included in the criteria for diagnosis of ADHD?

choices.text: Symptoms begin before 7 years of age
Symptoms should be present for at least 6 months
Should be reported by independent observers
Behaviour must be developmentally inappropriate  in two or more settings

questions.solution:
Attention-deficit hyperactive disorder (ADHD) must begin before 12 years of age, according to DSM-5 criteria. It was 7 years as per the previous DSM-4 criteria.

DSM-5 Diagnostic Criteria for attention-deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)-
1. A persistent pattern of inattention and/or hyperactivity/impulsivity present for at least 6 months, that interferes with functioning or development.
2. Several inattentive or hyperactive/impulsive symptoms were present before 12 years of age.
3. Several inattentive or hyperactive/impulsive symptoms are present in 2 or more settings (e.g., at school [or work] or at home) and is documented independently.
4. There is clear evidence of clinically significant impairment in social, academic, or occupational functioning.
 5. Symptoms do not occur exclusively during the course of schizophrenia, or another psychotic disorder, and are not better accounted for by another mental disorder (e.g., mood disorder, anxiety disorder, dissociative disorder, personality disorder, substance intoxication or withdrawal).

 

Treatment: Presynaptic dopaminergic agonists, commonly called psychostimulant medications, including methylphenidate, dexmethylphenidate, amphetamine, and various amphetamine and dextroamphetamine preparations are used.

A recent trial shows that Omega-3 fish oil supplements can improve attention in children with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)  as much as drug treatments, but only in those whose blood levels of omega-3 are low.

questions.text: In the image given below, the weight and height of a child are plotted against his age in years. Identify the correct statement.

choices.text: WHO growth charts used now are developed by National Center for Health Statistics (NCHS).
Short stature is defined as a height below 5th percentile.
Puberty in this child will be normal.
Bone age of this child is less than chronological age.

questions.solution:
Bone age of this child is less than chronological age, as seen in cases of constitutional delay.

As seen in the graph, the child was short initially, but the final height is within normal range. Hence, this child has constitutional delay.

Other options:

  • The WHO growth charts are based on Multicentre Growth Reference Study (MGRS). National Center for Health Statistics (NCHS) developed growth charts that were used in the past.
  • Short stature is defined as a height below the third percentile or more than 2 standard deviations below the median height for age and gender (<-2 SD) according to the population standard.
  • Puberty will be delayed in this child.

questions.text: Identify the correct statement from the following.

choices.text: Children with pica are at increased risk of megaloblastic anemia
Breath-holding spells are associated with hypertonia
Thumbsucking in a child is a way of discharging tension
Bedwetting after a period of 3 months of dryness at night is called secondary enuresis

questions.solution:
Thumbsucking in a child is a way of discharging tension. It is a self-limiting habit disorder, usually seen between 6 months to 2 years.

Option A: Pica is persistent ingestion of non-nutritive substances for at least 1 month. It hampers the development of the child and requires clinical attention. Children with pica are at an increased risk of lead poisoning, iron-deficiency anemia, and parasitic infections.

Option B: Breath-holding spells: It is preceded by a provocative event such as anger. Crying stops at full expiration. Child may have apnoea, cyanosis, pallor, hypotonia, or even loss of consciousness, and generalized tonic–clonic seizure (GTCS). Subtypes include cyanotic, pallid, and mixed episodes. Seizures and cardiac causes should be ruled out. Parents should be reassured that breath-holding spells are self-limiting.

Option D: Enuresis:

  • When the child has never been dry, it is called primary enuresis.
  • When the bedwetting starts after a minimum period of six months of dryness at night, it is termed as secondary enuresis.
  • Nocturnal enuresis is caused due to maturational delay. In a normal individual, antidiuretic hormone (ADH) levels usually peak between 4 am and 8 am. This circadian rhythm is impaired in nocturnal enuresis, leading to bedwetting.
  • Treatment - Behavioural therapy with positive reinforcement, bladder alarms, and desmopressin reserved for cases resistant to behavioural therapy.

questions.text: As part of the annual school health check-up camp, the visual acuity of a 6-year-old girl is being tested by the optometrist. What is the expected visual acuity in this age?
questions.solution:
According to Parson's diseases of the eye, visual acuity of 20/20 is attained by the age of 6 years. Nelson's Textbook of Paediatrics mentions that by the age of 5 or 6 years most children attain 20/20 vision.

Generally accepted visual acuity according to age:

  • Visual acuity of 20/40 at 3 years of age
  • Visual acuity of 20/30 at 4 years of age
  • Visual acuity of 20/20 at 5 or 6 years of age

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy was brought to the clinic by his mother who complains that for the past few months he has developed body-rocking movements and repeats words he hears on the television. He doesn’t respond immediately on calling his name and also makes limited eye contact during interactions. Based on clinical examination you suspect autism in the child. Which of the following screening tools can be used to detect the boy’s condition?
questions.solution:
The symptoms are suggestive of Autism - which is a pervasive developmental disorder characterized by:

  • Impairment in quality of social interaction
  • Impairment in quality of communication
  • Restricted, repetitive, and stereotyped patterns of behaviors and interests  

Common symptoms of Autism Spectrum Disorder -

  • Repetition of set words and phrases (echolalia)
  • Absent or delayed response to name being called, despite normal hearing
  • Reduced or absent responsive social smiling
  • Reduced or absent social use of eye contact 
  • Reduced social interactions 
  • Lacking the ability to initiate or sustain an interaction with peers or adults
  • Stereotypic movements and repetitive behaviors may include hand flapping, finger movements, body rocking, and lunging
  • Overly sensitive to noise, smells, or texture and may scream when they hear a siren or vacuum 

Modified Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (MCHAT) is a screening tool for the detection of autism.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is concerned about the change in colour of his scrotum since the last few weeks. On examination, the boy has a dark scrotum with normal-sized testis,  with coarse and curly pubic hair. What is the sexual maturity rating of this boy?
questions.solution:
The stage at which the pubic hair is coarse, curly and scrotum become dark is SMR stage 4.

The first visible sign of puberty in males is testicular enlargement at 9.5 years, which is a hallmark of SMR stage 2. This is followed by penile growth during SMR 3.

choices.text: Macrocephaly is defined as an occipitofrontal circumference greater than 3 SD above the mean for age and sex
Microcephaly is defined as an occipitofrontal circumference more than 2 SD below the mean for age and sex
Infants with benign familial megalencephaly have normal head circumference at birth

questions.solution:
Microcephaly is defined as an occipitofrontal circumference more than 2 SD below the mean for age and sex.

Macrocephaly is defined as an occipitofrontal circumference more than 2 SD above the mean for age and sex.

Monosomy 1p36 is associated with microcephaly.

Infants with benign familial megalencephaly have increased head circumference at birth.

Important causes of macrocephaly:

  • Megalencephaly (enlargement of the brain parenchyma)
    • Benign familial
    • Neurocutaneous syndromes such as neurofibromatosis, tuberous sclerosis
    • Lysosomal storage diseases: Tay–Sachs, mucopolysaccharidosis, gangliosidosis
  • Increased cerebrospinal fluid
    • Hydrocephalus
    • Benign enlargement of subarachnoid space
    • Hydranencephaly (absence of cerebral hemispheres; the cranial cavity is filled with cerebrospinal fluid [CSF])
  • Enlarged vascular compartment
    • Arteriovenous malformation
    • Subdural, epidural, subarachnoid, or intraventricular hemorrhage
  • Increase in the bony compartment
    • Bone disease: Achondroplasia, osteogenesis imperfecta
    • Bone marrow expansion: Thalassemia major
  • Miscellaneous causes
    • Intracranial mass lesions: Cyst, abscess, or tumor
    • Raised intracranial pressure: Idiopathic pseudotumor cerebri

questions.text: A mother brings her baby of 14 months to the clinic after being concerned about the shape of the baby’s head. You are suspecting a case of craniosynostosis. The premature fusion of which of the following suture is seen in this child?
questions.solution:
The picture is suggestive of a child with left posterior plagiocephaly (as the left side of the head is flattened) which involves the premature fusion of the left lambdoid suture.

In the case of a left anterior plagiocephaly, the premature fusion of the left coronal suture is seen.

Other deformities of the skull:

Deformity Suture involved
Anterior Plagiocephaly Respective side coronal suture
Posterior Plagiocephaly Respective side lambdoid suture
Deformation Plagiocephaly Positional skull flattening (without suture fusion)
Brachycephaly Bilateral Coronal suture
Trigonocephaly Metopic suture
Scaphocephaly Saggital suture

 

Craniosynostosis consists of premature fusion of one or more cranial sutures, resulting in an abnormal head shape.

  • Primary craniosynostosis: It results from a primary defect of ossification.
  • Secondary craniosynostosis: It results from the failure of brain growth.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy was found to have a height for age 2 standard deviations below the median. Furthermore, his bone age was found to be equal to chronological age. Which of the following is most likely?
questions.solution:
Familial short stature is most likely as bone age is equal to chronological age.

Bone age is more than chronological age in precocious puberty.

Bone age is less than chronological age in all other causes of short stature such as constitutional delay, undernutrition, genetic diseases, and endocrine causes.
